Graphical abstract Starting from structured supports based on compact spheres coated with a thin and porous layer of ZnAl2O4, mono and bimetallic catalysts were prepared. These catalysts were applied for the n-butane dehydrogenation reaction to produce light olefins. The structured supports were synthesized by coating with: bohemite-nitrate purified method (BP) and citrate-nitrate method (C). From the characterization results, the existence of strong Pt-Sn interaction in both bimetallic catalysts with probable alloys formation was found. In the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst, where higher metallic Pt-Sn interactions were observed, most of its metallic particles have sizes between 1 and 1.5 nm, which indicates a good metallic dispersion. These properties led to a catalyst with the best catalytic behavior, thus showing high yields to butenes, and a very good stability. Moreover, the presence of a structured support improves the mass and heat transference in this reaction carried out at high temperature. Keywords ZnAl2O4 structured support PtSn catalysts Thin films coating Butenes production 1 Introduction Catalysts obtained by coating of thin layers (with active species) on inert substrates, named structured catalysts, have recently gained importance due to the improvement in mass and heat transfer coefficients [1–4], compared to conventional catalysts, in rapid reactions carried out at high temperatures like n-alkanes dehydrogenation. With regard to substrates, various geometries such as tubes, platelets, honeycombs, and foams have been used. In addition, different coating materials like alumina, zirconium oxide, cupric oxide, alumina with ceria, lanthanum oxide or magnesium oxide have been employed in such procedures [2]. The direct catalytic reaction of alkanes dehydrogenation subjects the catalysts to very severe reaction conditions, since it is carried out at high temperatures, favoring the formation of coke, which deactivates the catalysts [5,6]. For this reason, it is necessary to periodically regenerate the catalysts with processes of oxidation [7,8]. The requirements for a good active phase for these catalysts are high selectivity to alkenes and catalytic stability. The most common metals used in dehydrogenation reactions are Pt or Pd accompanied by metallic promoters such as Sn, In, Ga and Ge [6,8–12]. The supports of the catalysts used in dehydrogenation processes must have low acidity and good interaction with metals. The first property is to avoid the cracking of alkanes and the second one is to ensure catalytic stability in reaction-regeneration cycles [5,7,8]. The materials most used as supports for dehydrogenation reactions are alumina [11,13,14], alumina with alkaline and alkaline-earth metals [15,16], silica [12,13], hydrotalcite [8,17,18] and MgAl2O4 [4,6,9,18]. Our research group and others studied PtSn catalysts supported on ZnAl2O4 powders for dehydrogenation reactions [5,19–22], however they cannot be used industrially in this way, in powder form, due to operation problems like pressure drop. Hence, an innovative way is to use structured supports with ZnAl2O4 coating for PtSn catalysts. In this research work we study Pt catalysts with Sn as metallic promoter for n-butane dehydrogenation reaction. These metals were supported on a thin and porous layer of ZnAl2O4, which coated compact spheres of alpha-alumina as inert substrate. The originality of this work lies on two main factors: the spherical geometry of the material to be coated, very little studied [4,11,23,24], and the coating material, ZnAl2O4, without any previous evidence for this application. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of supports The supports were prepared by coating of ZnAl2O4 on α-Al2O3 spheres. The spheres (2 mm diameter), provided by SASOL company, had very low specific surface (Sg = 5.0 m2 g−1). Materials employed for the coating process were: commercial bohemite, AlO(OH) (Disperal P2) provided by SASOL company, Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (Fluka, purity 99.5 %), Al(NO3)3.9H2O (Sigma Aldrich, purity 99.5 %) and citric acid, C6H8O7.H2O (Sigma Aldrich, purity 99.5 %). 2.1.1 Acid pre-treatment of α-Al2O3 spheres The spheres were pretreated with HCl 1 M solution in order to develop roughness in the compact material, which would improve the further adhesion of the coating layer. 2.1.2 Coating by bohemite-nitrate purified method (BP) Three suspensions of 5, 10 and 15 wt % of bohemite were prepared with the addition of nitric acid as stabilizing agent. After 48 h in the different suspensions, the gels were formed. A first layer with bohemite was obtained by immersion in the gel (5 wt %) of the spheres placed in a basket subjected to rotation. They were later dried in hot air flow. This process was repeated with the gels of 10 wt % and 15 wt %. Finally, the spheres were dried at 110 °C during 24 h. The bohemite-coated spheres were immersed in a beaker with a volume of a Zn(NO3)2.6H2O solution 0.5 M in order to achieve an Al/Zn molar ratio equal to 2. Afterwards, the beaker with the spheres was placed in furnace at 110 °C for 24 h and finally the coated spheres were calcined at 850 °C for 4 h in air flow. The XRD analysis of the layers material showed the ZnAl2O4 spinel formation and, what is more, the presence of ZnO as impurity (product of an incomplete reaction), Therefore, they were submitted to a purification treatment with (NH4)2CO3 solution, as in previous studies [19]. The characterization of these materials by SEM displayed that the spheres were uniformly coated with a layer of about 16 μm of thickness. The synthesized support was called Sp-Zn-BP, being Sp the α-Al2O3 spheres, Zn the ZnAl2O4, and BP the coating method. The synthesis and characterization of this structured material were analyzed previously [25], and two microphotographies of the coated sphere are shown in Fig. 1 . 2.1.3 Coating by citrate-nitrate method (C) A precursor solution of ZnAl2O4 was prepared by using Zn (NO3)2.6H2O, Al(NO3)3.9H2O and C6H8O7.H2O. In this solution, the amounts of the reagents were the necessaries to obtain a Al/Zn molar ratio equal to 2 and C6H8O7.H2O/nitrate ions molar ratio equal to 0.5. The spheres were placed in a beaker and a certain volume of the solution was added in order to achieve a [solution volume/weight spheres] ratio of 60 mL.g−1. Then, the solution (together with spheres) was heated with soft stirring up to boiling point, and was maintained under these conditions for 30 min in order to form a gel. The gel with the spheres were dried in vacuum furnace at 100 °C for 24 h. Then, the coated spheres were subjected to a complex thermal treatment that include heating in N2 flow until 500 °C, calcination in a flow of O2 (5%)-N2(95%) up to 700 °C and finally calcination in air flow at 800 °C. The diffractogram of the layer material showed the ZnAl2O4 spinel formation and only traces of the ZnO impurity. In this case, the purification treatment was not applied in order to determine the incidence of ZnO traces on the catalytic behavior. SEM microphotographs of this structured material showed a thin and rough layer coating the spheres with a uniform thickness of about 14 μm. The obtained support was called Sp-Zn-C. The synthesis and characterization of this structured material was previously studied by us [26], and two microphotographies of the coated sphere are displayed in Fig. 2 . 2.2 Catalysts preparation The Sp-Zn-C and Sp-Zn-BP supports were used for the preparation of Pt (0.3 wt%) and Pt (0.3 wt%) Sn (0.3 wt%) catalysts by incipient impregnation technique. The precursor solutions were chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6) and stannous chloride (SnCl2) with HCl (1 M). The [solution volume/support weight] ratio used for the impregnation process was 1.4 mL.g−1. The supports were immersed in a H2PtCl6 solution with the adequate concentration to obtain 0.3 wt % of Pt during 6 h at room temperature. Then, the precursors were dried 12 h at 110 °C in furnace and finally they were calcined in air flow (100 mL.min−1) for 3 h. For PtSn catalysts, the process described above was repeated until the drying step in furnace, after which the supports impregnated with Pt were immersed in the SnCl2 hydrochloric solution (6 h at room temperature) with the suitable concentration to achieve a Sn content of 0.3 wt%. Later, the samples were dried for 12 h at 110 °C and then, calcined 3 h in air flow at 500 °C. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The hydrogen chemisorption (H) experiments were carried out at room temperature in a static volumetric equipment. The procedure consisted of high vacuum degassing of the sample, reduction with hydrogen at 500 °C, and further degassing at 500 °C under vacuum. Then a hydrogen measurement was carried out at room temperature. The adsorption isotherms were linear in the pressure range used (50–250 mm Hg) and the chemisorbed hydrogen monolayer was calculated by extrapolating the isotherm to pressure equal to 0. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out by heating the samples from room temperature up to 600 °C with a 6 °C min−1 heating rate. The reducing mixture (5 %v / v H2-N2) was fed to the reactor with a flow rate of 9 mL.min−1. The catalysts were previously calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. The X-ray photolectronic spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were carried out in a Multitechnique Specs equipment with a dual X-ray source of Mg/Al (XR50 model) and a hemispheric PHOIBOS 150 analyzer in FAT mode. The spectra were obtained with step energy of 30 eV and a Mg anode operated at 100 W. The pressure during the measurement was less than 2.10−8 mbar. Samples (previously reduced) were supported on double-sided Cu tape and evacuated in ultra high vacuum prior to experiments. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were performed on a JEOL 100 CX II microscope with a nominal resolution of 6 Å. The operation conditions were acceleration voltage of 100 KV and magnification 45,000 × . The samples obtained by scrapping of the spheres layers were suspended in ethanol, which was then evaporated on the grid. A significant number of metal particles were measured in order to obtain the size distributions. The test reactions of metallic phase: cyclohexane dehydrogenation (CHD) and cyclopentane hydrogenolysis (CPH) were carried out in a differential flow reactor using a volumetric flow of 6 mL.h−1. Prior to the reactions, the catalysts were reduced "in situ" under H2 flow for 2 h at 500 °C and the reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography. The CPH was carried out at 500 °C using a H2/CP molar ratio equal to 22. The CHD was carried out at 300 °C (or 400 °C) using a H2/CH molar ratio equal to 26. The activation energy in CHD for different catalysts was obtained by Arrhenius plot, measuring the initial reaction rate at three temperatures close to 300 °C (or 400 °C). The conversion was lower than 7 % for all samples. Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) profiles of the used catalysts (after n-butane dehydrogenation reaction) were determined by using the TGA technique. Experiments were carried out in a SDTA Mettler STARe equipment. Both the samples and references (fresh catalysts) were stabilized under flowing N2 at 250 °C before TGA experiments. TGA experiments were carried out with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 from 250 to 500 °C under flowing air. 2.4 Catalytic tests in n-butane dehydrogenation reaction The experiments were carried out at 530 °C for 2 h in a quartz flow reactor. The reactor (with a catalyst weight of 0.200 g) was fed with 18 mL min–1 of the reactive mixture (n-butane + hydrogen, H2/n-C4H10 molar ratio = 1.25). All gases, n-butane, N2 (used for purge), and H2 were high purity ones (>99.99 %). Prior to the reaction, catalysts were reduced in situ at 530 °C under flowing H2 for 3 h. The reactor effluent was analyzed in a GC-FID equipment with a packed column (1/8 × 6 m, 20 wt.% BMEA on Chromosorb P-AW 60/80), which was kept at 50 °C during the analysis. With this analytical device, the amounts of methane, ethane, ethylene, propane, propylene, n-butane, 1-butene, cis-2-butene, trans-2-butene and 1,3 butadiene were measured. The n-butane conversion was calculated as the sum of the percentages of the chromatographic areas of all the reaction products (except H2) corrected by the corresponding response factor. The selectivity to the different reaction products (i) was defined as the ratio: mol of product i/Σ mol of all products (except H2). Taking into account the high temperatures used for the reaction, it was necessary to determine the contribution of the homogeneous reaction. For this purpose, a blank experiment was performed by using a quartz bed and the results showed a negligible n-butane conversion (<<1 %). 3 Results Figs. 3–5 show the results of n-butane dehydrogenation reaction for mono and bimetallic catalysts. Fig. 3 displays differences in the behavior of the monometallic catalysts, the Pt/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst have higher values of n-butane conversion through the reaction time than the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst. The addition of Sn to the Pt catalysts improves the conversion values of the monometallic catalysts, especially the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst, which showed conversion values that practically duplicated those of the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst. Besides the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst displayed the best performance of all catalysts in n-butane conversion. With regard to the selectivity to butenes (Fig. 4 ), all catalysts showed high values between 94 to 98 %. However, there are small differences in favor of the bimetallic catalysts compared to their respective monometallic ones. Besides, it should be noted that the selectivity values of the catalysts supported in Sp-Zn-C were slightly higher than those supported in Sp-Zn-BL. Fig. 5 displays the yields to butenes (which is defined as the product of the n-butane conversion and the selectivity to butenes) for all catalysts. This figure shows very similar curves to those of Fig. 3. The highest yield to butenes values corresponded to the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst, however, this sample showed a significant drop in yield values (ΔY = 23 %) along the reaction time. This means that the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst displayed a low catalytic stability. The PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst showed lower yield values than that PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst. The yield to butenes values for PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst ranged between 20.6 and 19.5 % (Fig. 5) showing good catalytic stability (ΔY = 5 %), which is better than the one from the corresponding monometallic catalyst (ΔY = 12 %). With respect to the amount of deposited coke during the reaction, Temperature Programmed Oxidation (TPO) experiments for the samples after reaction were performed, observing that the carbon contents of both bimetallic catalysts were negligible (less than 0.1 wt%). The results of hydrogen chemisorption and test reactions (cyclohexane dehydrogenation, CHD and cyclopentane hydrogenolisis, CPH) are shown in Table 1 . There is a sharp decrease of the hydrogen chemisorption values in the bimetallic catalysts compared to the corresponding monometallic catalysts. This fact can be attributed to geometric and/or electronic effects of the Sn promoter on the Pt sites, or to a significant increase in the size of the metallic particles of Pt in bimetallic catalysts. However, when presenting TEM results, this last hypothesis will be discarded. With regard to the CHD reaction, it is a structure-insensitivity one [27], whose activation energy can be changed by electronic effects, derived from the presence of a second metal or from the interaction with the support. In this reaction, it can be observed a marked decrease of the initial reaction rate value of PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst respect to monometallic one. This fact, together with the hydrogen chemisorption results, indicates that in this bimetallic catalyst, there would be blocking effects of the active sites of Pt by the Sn atoms. On the other hand, the PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst is practically inactive at 300 °C in CH reaction, while the corresponding monometallic one has an initial rate value of 11 mol CH g Pt−1 h−1. This would also indicate the presence of blocking effects of the promoter on Pt sites in PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP sample. Concerning the values of activation energy of cyclohexane dehydrogenation reaction (ECH), the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst shows an important increase with respect to the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst (Table 1), which indicates the presence of electronic effects of Sn on the actives sites of Pt in this bimetallic catalyst. Since the PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst is not active in the reaction at 300 °C, its activation energy could not be determined therein. For this reason, experiments were carried out at 400 °C for mono and bimetallic catalysts supported in Sp-Zn-BP, which yielded the following results: ECH PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP = 31.3 Kcal mol CH−1 and ECH Pt/Sp-Zn-BP = 7.5 Kcal mol CH−1. These results point in the direction of possible electronic modifications of the Sn promoter on the Pt atoms in PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst. Regarding the results of the CPH reaction, as shown in Table 1, all samples show low hydrogenolytic activity. This phenomenon has already been observed [19] and can be explained by the structure of metallic particles deposited on ZnAl2O4. In fact, Aguilar-Ríos et al. [28] studied Pt/ZnAl2O4 catalysts by using TEM and found that the metallic particles would have a rounded shape with very low density of steps and edges, which are the active sites for the hydrogenolysis reactions [27]. In conclusion, according to the results showed in Table 1, both bimetallic catalysts present geometric and electronic effects of the Sn promoter on Pt sites, indicating strong Pt-Sn interactions. Figs. 6 and 7 display the profiles of temperature programmed reduction (TPR) for mono and bimetallic catalysts. The Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst showed a main reduction peak located at 93 °C and a shoulder at 150 °C (Fig. 6a). These signals can be attributed to the reduction of the different oxidized Pt species [29]. The main peak would correspond to the reduction of PtO2, while the shoulder at higher temperature can be assigned to the reduction of oxychlorinated Pt species. The PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst showed a main reduction peak located at 235 °C, a shoulder at 110 °C and reduction area between 450–550 °C (Fig. 6b). The main peak would correspond to a co-reduction of Pt and Sn or of intermetallic species, since this peak is shifted to higher temperatures and has a higher area than that observed in the monometallic catalyst. These facts point to an important interaction between platinum and tin with probable alloy formation or intermetallic compound conformation. The shoulder at 110 °C could correspond to a small fraction of free Pt species since it appears at a temperature close to the monometallic catalyst reduction peak. The small reduction zone at high temperatures observed in Fig. 6b can be attributed to the reduction of oxidized species of Sn in contact with the support [19]. Fig. 7 displays TPR profiles corresponding to Pt and PtSn catalysts supported on Sp-Zn-C. Fig. 7a shows three peaks, which can be also attributed to the reduction of different oxidized platinum species. It must be highlighted that this phenomenon was not observed in other studies about Pt/ZnAl2O4 powder catalysts [19,20]. The peaks in Fig. 7a are located at temperatures of 117, 209 and 235 °C. The first signal would correspond to the reduction of PtO2 compound. The peaks located at 209 and 235 °C can be attributed to two different PtOxCly species. In relation to the bimetallic catalyst (Fig. 7b), the same three peaks are observed as in the case of the Pt catalyst, but at larger scale. This fact also points in the direction of a Pt-Sn co-reduction phenomenon. In conclusion, both bimetallic catalysts showed strong Pt-Sn interactions, but the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst seems to have a higher degree of interaction due to the important increase in the main reduction peak area compared to the corresponding monometallic catalyst, and also, due to the significant temperature shift of this reduction peak. XPS spectra for bimetallic catalysts are shown in Figs. 8–11 . The Pt 4f signal, the most intense for platinum, overlaps with two Al 2p signals coming from the support. However, it is possible to separate them and make the deconvolution for both signals. Fig. 8 shows the Pt 4f and Al 2p signals for PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst. The presence of the Pt 4f5/2 and 4f7/2 doublet, placed at 71.2 and 74.5 eV of binding energy, indicates the existence of zerovalent Pt [30] in this reduced catalyst. In the same way, in the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst the Pt 4f5/2 and 4f7/2 doublet, located at 71.7 and 75.0 eV of binding energy is shown in Fig. 10. In both samples, only the presence of Pt (0) was observed. This was confirmed by analyzing the Pt 4d signal, which was much less intense than Pt 4f one and therefore had more noise than the main signal. Fig. 9 shows the Sn 3d5/2 signal for PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst. This signal was deconvoluted in two peaks located at 484.4 eV and 486.2 eV. The first peak might correspond to Sn alloyed with Pt [12], while the second one can be attributed to tin oxides [12,30]. Fig. 11 also shows two peaks derived from the deconvolution of the Sn 3d5/2 signal, which might correspond to alloyed tin (485.3 eV) and tin oxides (486.8 eV), for PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst. The difference between both catalysts is the proportion of alloyed tin in respect to total surface tin species. In the PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst, the percentage of alloyed tin is 13%, while in the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst it is 39%. This difference can be associated to the phenomenon observed in TPR experiments, where higher interaction between Pt and Sn metals in the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst was observed. This process could lead to the Pt-Sn alloys formation. Figs. 12–15 show the results of the measurement of metallic particle sizes obtained by TEM. Both the distribution and the average particle size are similar for Pt and PtSn catalysts supported in Sp-Zn-C, as shown in Figs. 12 and 13. The size distribution is narrow with most metallic particles between 1.0 and 1.5 nm, and the mean diameter (D) is 1.4 nm (see TEM images in Supplementary Figs. S1 and S3). For the catalysts supported in Sp-Zn-BP, the particle sizes distribution of Pt catalyst was different to that from PtSn catalyst. In the first sample, there is a larger amount of metallic particles of sizes between 1.5 and 2.0 nm (Fig. 14) compared to the size distribution of the bimetallic catalyst displayed in Fig. 15. In consequence, the PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst have a mean particle diameter slightly smaller than that of Pt/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst (see TEM images in Supplementary Figs. S2 and S4). In both bimetallic catalysts, the influence of Sn addition to Pt catalysts in the mean diameter of metallic particle was not significant. To sum up, the catalysts have very small metal particles and a narrow size distribution, with predominance of particles between 1.0 and 1.5 nm. 4 Discussion Taking into account the TEM results it is observed that both monometallic catalysts have equal particle mean diameter, however, the metallic dispersion derived from hydrogen chemisorption results showed differences between these catalysts. The calculation of metallic dispersion (D) from TEM measurements by using the expression D = 1.13/d [31], where d is the average particle size in nm, results in 80 % for Pt/Sp-Zn-BP and Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalysts. This estimation is close to the D measured by hydrogen chemisorption for the Pt/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst (see Table 1). The discrepancy with Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst might be the result of the presence of ZnO as an impurity in the Sp-Zn-C material [26], which can form Pt-Zn alloys, thus affecting the properties of the metallic phase of this catalyst. Taking into consideration that alloys of platinum decrease the amount of chemisorbed hydrogen [8,13,32,33], the low value of H2 chemisorption of Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst showed in Table 1 can be attributed to the presence of Pt-Zn alloys in this sample, as found by Boccuzzi et al. in Pt/ZnO catalysts [34]. This phenomenon would also explain the low activity of the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst in the n-butane dehydrogenation reaction (see Fig. 3). In this sense, Pakhomov et al. [35] found that Pt/ZnAl2O4 catalysts, with ZnO impurity in the support, had low activity in the n-butane dehydrogenation reaction. Taking into account the dispersion values calculated from the particle size (which do not have the disadvantage of being distorted by electronic effects in the metallic phase as discussed above), the dispersions of the bimetallic catalysts were calculated, giving values of 80% for PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst and 86% for PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst. Based on these metal dispersions, the TOF values in n-butane dehydrogenation reaction for all catalysts were calculated. These results are presented in Fig. 3. The TOF values show the same tendency that the n-butane conversion values, that is the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst has the highest TOF values of all catalysts. Concerning the CPH, a structure sensitive reaction [27], both monometallic catalysts present very low hydrogenolytic activity, as seen in the very low values of R0 CP in Table 1. This property of the Pt catalysts supported on ZnAl2O4 was previously observed by Aguilar-Ríos et al. [28] and Bocanegra et al. [19]. The first work found, through TEM measurements, that the Pt particles supported on ZnAl2O4 showed a rounded shape with very low density of steps and edges. These sites are the most active for hydrogenolysis reactions [27]. These results referring to the structure of the metallic particles of Pt and the formation of Pt-Zn alloys show that the Pt supported on ZnAl2O4 has different characteristics to those of the Pt supported on MgAl2O4, which was studied in a previous work [4]. The CHD test reaction is considered structure insensitive [27], and its rate-limiting step on Pt surfaces is the benzene desorption [36]. Table 1 shows that the initial reaction rate (R0 CH) of the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst is higher than that of the Pt/Sp-Zn-BP catalyst. This behavior could be explained taking into account the foregoing information about the presence of Pt-Zn alloys in the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst. According to Consonni el al. [37], the Pt sites, when alloying to Zn, form Pt−δ–Zn+δ entities where the Pt atom is electron-rich and repels the electrons of the CC bond, facilitating the benzene desorption. With respect to PtSn/Sp-Zn-C bimetallic catalyst, a marked increase in the activity of this sample respect to corresponding monometallic one was observed (see Fig. 3). The Sn addition to the Pt/Sp-Zn-C catalyst produced an important change in the catalytic behavior, which could be associated to a modification of the metallic phase. In this sense, Pakhomov et al. [21] studied PtSn/ZnAl2O4 catalysts and did not find PtZn alloys in the samples with Sn/Pt molar ratio > 1. Moreover, there is an increase in catalytic stability in PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst respect to the corresponding monometallic one, as shown in Fig. 5. Considering the other bimetallic catalyst (PtSn/Sp-Zn-BP), the Sn addition to the monometallic catalyst also produced both an increase in n-butane conversion and in the catalytic stability. The role of the Sn addition on the catalytic properties of PtSn catalysts supported on different materials and used in the hydrocarbons dehydrogenation reactions has been discussed in many previous works [12,14,18,19,33,38]. Agreement has been reached on the fact that a strong Pt-Sn interaction favors catalytic behavior in dehydrogenation. Although it has been reported that the presence of metallic tin can decrease the catalytic activity [14,21,38], it is also true that the presence of electronic effects of the Sn atoms on the Pt sites, with possible alloys formation, favors both the selectivity to olefins and the stability of the metallic phase [12,16,19,33,39]. However, the presence of tin in ionic form has been highlighted by other researchers as playing an important role in improving the catalytic behavior of PtSn catalysts [14,39,40]. A complex metallic phase has been proposed for the PtSn catalysts, where Pt sites coexist with small PtSn alloy clusters and ionic tin at the platinum-support interface. This work confirms the existence of strong Pt-Sn interaction in both bimetallic catalysts through the results of TPR experiments, CHD reaction (test reaction of the metallic phase), hydrogen chemisorption and XPS analysis. TPR results of bimetallic catalysts showed an increase of reduction area and shifts to higher temperatures of the main reduction peaks, indicating co-reduction of PtSn with alloy formation or intermetallic compound conformation. The important decrease of initial rate values of CHD points towards the existence of geometric effects of the Sn atoms on Pt sites. The marked increase in activation energy values (ECH) indicates the presence of strong electronic effects of tin on platinum sites, with possible alloys formation. The drop in hydrogen chemisorption values of bimetallic catalysts regard to the corresponding Pt catalysts also indicates a clear influence of tin on the platinum sites through geometric and/or electronic effects. Moreover, XPS results show that Sn is in two oxidation states, a minor proportion alloyed with Pt, and a higher proportion as ionic tin, probably close to Pt-support interface. The catalyst with higher proportion of alloyed tin (39 %) was the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C one. In this catalyst, 80 % of their metallic particles had sizes between 1 and 1.5 nm according to TEM results, which indicates a very good metallic dispersion. These properties led to a catalyst with the best catalytic behavior, thus showing yields to butenes between 26.5 % and 20.4 %. Another important factor for the improvement of the catalytic performance of these samples is the presence of a structured support consisting of a porous external layer of small thickness (between 15 and 20 μm). Hence, the active phase is deposited on the external surface of the catalyst, improving the mass and heat transference. This would allow the rapid diffusion of the reactant (n-butane) to the active centers located in the layer, the fast reaction, and the immediate desorption of the formed olefins, thus avoiding the formation of undesirable products and increasing the selectivity to butenes. 5 Conclusions Structured supports composed of thin, uniform and stable porous layers of ZnAl2O4 coating alpha-alumina spheres were obtained by two synthesis methods. These supports showed a good ability to disperse metals. In fact, the catalysts displayed very small metallic particles with a predominance of sizes between 1 and 1.5 nm and a narrow size distribution. In addition, the particles seems to have a structure with low concentration of edges, corners and steps, which explain the low hydrogenolytic activity and the high dehydrogenating selectivity to butenes. Characterization results show strong intermetallic interactions, with possible PtSn alloys formation. The addition of Sn to Pt catalysts improves the behavior in n-butane dehydrogenation reaction, especially the stability of its catalytic properties. This improvement is more marked in the case of the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst, which exhibits very good yields to butenes. With respect to the presence of ZnO in the Sp-Zn-C support, this impurity decreased the activity of the monometallic catalyst. However, the Sn addition to Pt catalyst produced an important modification of the metallic phase, enhancing the catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: Starting from structured supports based on compact spheres coated with a thin and porous layer of ZnAl2O4, mono and bimetallic catalysts were prepared. These catalysts were applied for the n-butane dehydrogenation reaction to produce light olefins. The structured supports were synthesized by coating with: bohemite-nitrate purified method (BP) and citrate-nitrate method (C). From the characterization results, the existence of strong Pt-Sn interaction in both bimetallic catalysts with probable alloys formation was found. In the PtSn/Sp-Zn-C catalyst, where higher metallic Pt-Sn interactions were observed, most of its metallic particles have sizes between 1 and 1.5 nm, which indicates a good metallic dispersion. These properties led to a catalyst with the best catalytic behavior, thus showing high yields to butenes, and a very good stability. Moreover, the presence of a structured support improves the mass and heat transference in this reaction carried out at high temperature.
coredata.dc:title: New PtSn structured catalysts with ZnAl2O4 thin film for n-butane dehydrogenation reaction
